update.description:
Add `//model/@canonical_link` attribute that specifies the name of the model's canonical link, to which the model's implicit frame is attached. If unset, the first link in the model is chosen. This is based on the following section of the proposal:

* http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs&#2-model-frame-and-canonical-link

It implies that a model must have at least one link. A new error code is added for this case and tested with example sdf files.

`ign sdf --check` also checks that the canonical_link attribute matches a link in the model and has tests.
update.title: [Citadel] sdf 1.7: add `//model/@canonical_link` attribute and require models to have at least one link

content.raw: Didn't think it had to be a pointer, but I'm good with this.
content.html: Didn't think it had to be a pointer, but I'm good with this.

content.raw: I broke the build by moving this here without including `"sdf/Root.hh"`. If we pass a pointer to the `sdf::Root`, then we can forward-declare the class instead of including the header file
content.html: I broke the build by moving this here without including "sdf/Root.hh". If we pass a pointer to the sdf::Root, then we can forward-declare the class instead of including the header file

content.raw: It would be nice to have a function that returns a pointer to the canonical link. Without it, users have to handle the two cases where `CanonicalLinkName` returns an empty string or a link name and call `LinkByIndex` or `LinkByName` accordingly.
content.html: It would be nice to have a function that returns a pointer to the canonical link. Without it, users have to handle the two cases where CanonicalLinkName returns an empty string or a link name and call LinkByIndex or LinkByName accordingly.
